sentence: Toothpaste, diapers, razors, potato chips -- these are not the type of sexy products that excite investors.
But over the long term, they have been the type of products that have helped generate very exciting returns for investors.

Consider the work of quantitative investment guru James O'Shaughnessy, author of What Works On Wall Street and one of the investing greats upon whose writings I base one of my Guru Strategy computer models.
In the updated version of his book, O'Shaughnessy examines how various stock market sectors have performed over more than four decades.
Perhaps his most interesting finding: that the consumer staples sector -- home to those diapers and razors and potato chips -- has produced the best returns over that period.
And, it's done so while being one of the least risky sectors in the market.
From 1968 through 2009, O'Shaughnessy found, consumer staples averaged compound annual returns of 13.57%, beating the next-best sector (financials) by 1.2 percentage points per year.
And, the sector had the second-lowest standard deviation out of the market's 10 sectors; the only one that was less volatile was utilities.
O'Shaughnessy says this is probably a surprise to many, but adds that it shouldn't be, when you think about it.
"Industries that make goods and services that people have to buy, regardless of economic circumstances, are bound to do well whatever the economic conditions," he writes.

He adds that the sector is also filled with companies that have wide economic moats that protect them against competition, and strong brand recognition -- which he says are major advantages for a business.
If that last part sounds familiar, it should.
The great Warren Buffett has made famous the idea of "economic moats".
He has also built his empire in part on consumer staples stocks.
Currently, his Berkshire Hathaway owns stakes in such staples giants as Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble, and Johnson & Johnson.
If, like Buffett, you focus on the strongest of the consumer staples stocks, you can really make out well over the long haul.

O'Shaughnessy found that buying staples companies in the top quintile based on shareholder yield (buyback yield plus dividend yield) led to 17.8% compounded returns over the 42-year period his study covered.
And, they did so with a lower standard deviation and a lower maximum drawdown than the sector as a whole.
O'Shaughnessy's findings got me wondering about which consumer staples stocks currently get the highest marks from my Guru Strategies.
Here are some of the best of the bunch, including several that my O'Shaughnessy-inspired models rate highly.

PepsiCo, Inc. ( PEP ): In addition to its signature cola, this New York State-based company makes a wide variety of other beverages and snacks, with brands that include Doritos, Gatorade, Tropicana, Lay's, and Quaker Oats.
Pepsi hasn't produced a whole lot of earnings growth in recent years, but it is still a quality business, with a 32% return on equity over the past 12 months.
Pepsi is the sort of large, solid company that my O'Shaughnessy value approach likes.
It's big ($143 billion market cap, more than $65 billion in sales over the past year), has $6.19 in cash flow per share (vs. the market mean of $1.72), and offers a 2.9% dividend yield.
Procter & Gamble Company ( PG ): This consumer staples giant ($223 billion market cap) boasts such big brand names as Bounty, Tide, and Crest.
The Cincinnati-based firm is active in about 180 countries across the world, and has taken in nearly $80 billion in sales over the past 12 months.
Its size is part of what my O'Shaughnessy value model likes about P&G.
So is the firm's $4.75 in cash flow per share, and its 3.2% dividend yield.

Pilgrim's Pride Corporation ( PPC ): Greeley, Colo.-based Pilgrim's works with approximately 4,000 family farms throughout the U.S. and Mexico, and is the second-largest chicken producer in the world.
It has operations in 12 U.S. states as well as in Mexico and Puerto Rico.
The $5.5-billion-market-cap firm has taken in more than $8.5 billion in sales over the past year.
While its shares have stumbled recently amid bird flu hype, Pilgrim's gets strong interest from my Joel Greenblatt-based model.
The approach likes its 22.6% earnings yield (EBIT/enterprise value) and 62% return on capital (EBIT/tangible capital employed), and ranks it as the 3rd-best stock in the market.
Snyder's-Lance, Inc. ( LNCE ): This snack food company has such core brands as Snyder's of Hanover, Lance, Cape Cod, Snack Factory, Pretzel Crisps and Late July.
The $2.3-billion-market-cap firm has taken in $1.7 billion in sales over the past year.
Snyder's is a favorite of my O'Shaughnessy-based growth model.
It looks for firms that have upped earnings per share in each year of the past five-year period, which Snyder's has done.

The model also looks for a key combination of variables: a high relative strength, which is a sign the market is embracing the stock, and a low price/sales ratio, which is a sign it hasn't gotten too pricey.
Snyder's has a solid 12-month relative strength of 80, and its P/S ratio of just 1.4 comes in below this model's 1.5 upper limit.
Unilever ( UN ): With head offices in London and The Netherlands, this home goods and food products firm counts Lipton, Hellmann's, Dove, Slim-Fast, and Vaseline among its big brand names.
My O'Shaughnessy-inspired value model likes Unilever's size ($134 billion market cap), $2.50 in cash flow per share, and solid 3.1% dividend yield.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
